trial_identification.studytitle: Ideal Treadmill Speed To Stimulate Walking Steps In Babies
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Ideal Treadmill Speed To Stimulate Walking Steps In Babies

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal musculoskeletal and cartilage development and function

interventions.interventions: The infant was submitted a once time in four random belt speeds of the treadmill (0.1, 0.16, 0.22 e 0.28 m/s) during one minute each one, with passive reflective marcs in left shoulder, left hip, left knee, left ankle, and left fifth metatarsal to kinematics analysis, and filmed by a camera

primaryOutcome.outcome: descriptives variables of the foot step (cadence, step speed, step duration and step length)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: film analyses of the four ten attempts (software Ariel Performance Analyses System - APAS), once only at end of intervention

primaryOutcome.outcome: temporal variables of foot step (stance, first double support, single support and second double support)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: film analyses of the four ten attempts (software Ariel Performance Analyses System - APAS), once only at end of intervention

primaryOutcome.outcome: coordinatives variables of foot step (interlimb coordination)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: film analyses of the four ten attempts (software Ariel Performance Analyses System - APAS), once only at end of intervention

primaryOutcome.outcome: temporal series of joint angles (ankle, knee and hip)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: film analyses of the four ten attempts (software Ariel Performance Analyses System - APAS), once only at end of intervention

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: health babies, previous to walking onset (cruising)

ethicsAndSummary.summary: purpose of the study: investigate the effects of different treadmill belt speeds on babies foot steps. Hypothesys: 1. In the highest belt speeds, the foot steps look like mature gait in the kinematics parameters; 2. In the highest belt speeds, the descriptive, temporal and coordenatives variables of the babies foot steps look like the mature gait. 3. The highest belt speeds (0.22 and 0.28 m/s) are the best speeds to stimulate foot steps in babies in the treadmill
